section.title: The Tableau Theme
section.para: For the 2012.3 release, &product.longname;'s default theme showcases a "tablet-first" approach to web site design. Dubbed Tableau, the theme uses magazine-like styling with large photos and generous whitespace, implements gesture-based navigation using horizontal and vertical swipes, and adapts to various sized mobile devices and orientations. These features allow &product.name; to provide a web site that resembles a native mobile device application with no installation or programming required.
This section describes the presentation and navigation aspects of the theme, and identifies areas of &product.name; that differ from other themes in order to work well on mobile devices.

section.title: Tableau Features
section.para: The home page cycles through a selection of full-screen images and provides a top-level menu for quick access to feature stories:
Swiping to the left brings the story grid into view:
The grid is comprised of widgets, and can span multiple pages; swipe left or right to navigate the grid. Tapping on a content entry from the front page or the grid slides the content into view:
Subsequent pages are auto-paginated to fit your mobile device's screen size:

warning.title: Perform Administrative Functions in a Desktop Browser
warning.para: The Tableau theme is intended for anonymous users to experience. For administrative functions, please use a desktop browser.

section.title: Toolbar
section.para: The Tableau theme's presentation occupies the full browser window. When you login to &product.name;, this means that the toolbar might obscure content, buttons, or links. The toolbar has an additional button to the right of the user menu to hide the toolbar when necessary:
When tapped, the toolbar slides out of view allowing access to obscured page elements. To bring the toolbar back, a new button appears in the top right of the display:

While viewing content, a Home and Back button may also appear in the top right of the display to provide navigation to the home page or a previously viewed page. These buttons appear light grey when there is nothing further to see in the indicated direction:
The grid and content pages provide Next and Prev buttons at the bottom of the display to navigate the current content:

section.title: Image Rotator
section.para: The cycling of images on the home page, or on the grid, is achieved with the Image Rotator widget. Images cross-fade as they cycle, however select devices also support panning and zooming during the cycle for a more interesting presentation.

Both the cover page and the grid have responsive layouts that would degrade quickly if the rotator's size was specified. For this reason, the rotator's width and height configuration fields are not available in these regions of the Tableau theme.

section.title: Editing Content
section.para: The traditional editing context that &product.name; provides does not work very well on a mobile device, so the WYSIWYG editor appears in a dialog:

section.title: Social Integrations
section.para: In most &product.name; themes, social integration features such as Comments, Disqus, and ShareThis enhance the presentation of content entries to include additional features. For the tableau theme, accessing these features is handled with buttons that appear in the footer:
For Comments and Disqus each link, when tapped, opens its respective display:

section.title: Image Gallery
section.para: When you tap on an image presented in an image gallery, the full image is displayed in a lightbox. Unlike the lightbox presented for other themes, you cannot navigate the gallery's images with previous/next arrows.
